title: 114_hr3295
content:
The Department of Justice is appropriated $140,000,000 for State and Local Law Enforcement Assistance for fiscal year 2015. This includes funding for various programs such as the Edward Byrne Memorial Justice Assistance Grant program, Drug Courts, mental health courts, programs to reduce gun crime and gang violence, and a veterans treatment courts program. For "Juvenile Justice Programs", an additional $10,000,000 is allocated for community-based violence prevention initiatives, focusing on public health approaches to reducing shootings and violence. An additional $30,000,000 is allocated for Community Oriented Policing Services Programs. $15,000,000 is for grants to State law enforcement agencies in high-seizure States for precursor chemicals and methamphetamine investigations. Another $15,000,000 is for grants to statewide law enforcement agencies in high opioid admission States for heroin and opioid trafficking investigations. INDEPENDENT AGENCIES

Small Business Administration: Additional funding for entrepreneurial development programs and business loans program account.

DEPARTMENT OF LABOR

Employment and Training Administration: Additional funding for training and employment services.

DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES

Health Resources and Services Administration: Additional funding for maternal and child health initiatives. For the Healthy Start Initiative, an additional $50,000,000 is allocated until September 30, 2016. The Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration receives $10,000,000 for drug court grants. The Department of Housing and Urban Development receives $170,000,000 for the Choice Neighborhoods Initiative. Additionally, the Community Planning and Development fund receives funding, including a transfer of funds. $500,000,000 is allocated for the Community Development Fund until September 30, 2016, to aid in emergency response, recovery, infrastructure restoration, and economic revitalization in distressed areas affected by violence or civil unrest in 2015. Funds will be awarded to states, tribes, or local governments based on criteria determined by the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development. The Community Development Fund allocates $500,000,000 until September 30, 2016, to aid in emergency response, recovery, infrastructure restoration, and economic revitalization in distressed areas affected by violence or civil unrest in 2015. Grantees must submit a plan detailing fund usage and criteria for eligibility. The Secretary will approve plans meeting specified criteria within 45 days. Funds shall not be allocated if the plan does not meet the criteria. The Secretary will approve plans meeting specified criteria within 45 days of enactment. If a plan does not meet the criteria, it will be disapproved. Grantees must receive training on grant management and incorporate performance requirements into contracts. The Secretary may waive certain requirements in connection with fund usage, except for fair housing, nondiscrimination, labor standards, and the environment. The Secretary may waive certain regulations for fund usage, excluding fair housing, nondiscrimination, labor standards, and the environment. Up to 30% of funds can be used for immediate community assistance. Up to $10,000,000 can be transferred for administrative costs. The Office of Lead Hazard Control and Healthy Homes is allocated an additional $30,000,000 for lead hazard reduction until September 30, 2016. General provisions include provisions for moving-to-work programs. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development is allocated $30,000,000 for lead hazard reduction until September 30, 2016. Moving-to-Work agreements for designated agencies are extended until fiscal year 2028 with reporting requirements for financial data. The Act designates each amount as an emergency requirement, subject to the President's subsequent designation and transmission to Congress. The Act is also known as the "Rebuilding Urban Inner Cities Is Long Overdue Act of 2015" or the "REBUILD Act."
